@graph.description:
The deformability of red blood cells (RBCs) is a critical factor in understanding cardiovascular diseases and serves as a key determinant of RBC lifespan. Red blood cells with different deformities were observed to exhibit significant differences in their morphological characteristics. To further investigate this relationship, we propose a deep learning-based approach to explore the correlation between RBC deformability and its morphological features. We utilize a dielectrophoretic microfluidic approach to assess deformability and capture microscopic images of erythrocytes. These images are then classified according to the deformability of the cells.
Based on the above research, this study contains three datasets. We characterize the deformability of RBCs using the strain of RBCs under the same dielectrophoretic force with the strain formula ε = (a−a0)/a0, where a is the length of the long axis of the RBCs stretched by the dielectrophoretic force and a0 is the original length of the RBCs. the strain between 0~0.3 is called hard, between 0.3~0.6 is called deformable, and the rest is called soft.
@graph.name: Original images for morphological analysis to assess the deformability of red blood cells

@graph.description: Red blood cells in pig blood
@graph.name: Red blood cells from pigs used in the laboratory

@graph.description: We used an optical microscope equipped with a camera (Ti2-U, Nikon, Japan) (VTSE3S2000, VIHENT, China) to observe and record the condition of RBCs passing through the chip, the eyepiece selection magnification of the microscope was 10×, the objective magnification was 40×, and the camera captured brightfield images with 2736×1824 pixels. The field of view of the microscope is placed at the intersection of the microfluidic channel and the ITO electrode, where the capture and stretching of RBCs can be recorded, and the images are recorded using the VistarImage4.0 software adapted to the camera.
@graph.labEquipment: An optical microscope (Ti2-U, Nikon, Japan) equipped with a camera (VTSE3S2000, VIHENT, China) was used to observe and record the condition of cells inside the chip.
@graph.name: Ti2-U, Nikon Microscopy
